diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Usually caused by Epstein-Barr virus, it presents with fever, sore throat, swollen lymph glands, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Rubella
diagnoses.description: Also known as German measles, it presents with rash, fever, and enlarged lymph nodes. Thrombocytosis can occur due to the body's response to the infection.

diagnoses.name: Rubeola (Measles)
diagnoses.description: Characterized by fever, cough, Koplik spots, and a characteristic rash, measles can lead to complications including thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet fever
diagnoses.description: A disease resulting from group A Streptococcus infection, presenting with sore throat, fever, a strawberry-like rash, and potential for thrombocytosis in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body, leading to symptoms like fever, rash, swollen lymph nodes, and redness in the palms and soles.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
diagnoses.description: A severe skin reaction to medication that includes fever, rash, lymphadenopathy, and hematologic abnormalities such as thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: HIV acute retroviral syndrome
diagnoses.description: Early stage of HIV infection that can present with fever, sore throat, rash, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Toxoplasmosis
diagnoses.description: An infection caused by the Toxoplasma gondii parasite, presenting with lymphadenopathy, maculopapular rash, and sometimes higher platelet counts.

diagnoses.name: Parvovirus B19 infection
diagnoses.description: Known for causing erythema infectiosum or fifth disease, it can present with fever, rash, joint pain, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Secondary syphilis
diagnoses.description: The second stage of syphilis, which can present with rash, fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy, along with potential hematologic changes.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: Kawasaki disease is a rare syndrome in children that involves inflammation of the blood vessels, leading to symptoms like fever, rash, eye redness, and swollen hands and feet. It typically requires prompt treatment to reduce the risk of complications.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes, often a reaction to a medication or an infection. Symptoms include flu-like symptoms followed by a painful red or purplish rash that spreads and blisters.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis
diagnoses.description: A severe skin condition that causes widespread redness and blistering of the skin and mucous membranes; often related to medication reactions. It's considered a more severe form of Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by toxin-producing strains of the bacteria Streptococcus pyogenes, known as group A beta-hemolytic streptococci. Symptoms include a sore throat, fever, headaches, swollen lymph nodes, and a characteristic rash.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reactions with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A drug reaction that causes a severe skin rash, along with fever, lymphadenopathy, hematological abnormalities, and involvement of internal organs.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, leading to a wide range of symptoms including rash and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)
diagnoses.description: A mild viral infection common in children, characterized by a facial rash that spreads to the rest of the body. Caused by parvovirus B19, it can also lead to fever and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Adult Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare type of inflammatory arthritis that features fevers, rash, and joint pain. Symptoms also often include sore throat and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Graft vs Host Disease (GVHD)
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when donated bone marrow or peripheral blood stem cells view the recipient’s body as foreign and attack the body. Symptoms can include skin rash, liver dysfunction, and GI disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Rubella
diagnoses.description: A contagious viral infection best known by its distinctive red rash. It's also known as German measles and can have more serious consequences if contracted by pregnant women, potentially affecting the fetus.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the kidneys, joints, and heart, with manifestations like nephritis, arthropathy, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by chronic inflammation of the joints (arthropathy) and can also involve other organs, causing symptoms like pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder with features of systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including nephritis and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that may result in changes to the skin, blood vessels, muscles, and internal organs, potentially causing nephritis and pericardial effusions.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium, often due to a viral infection, and can sometimes be associated with systemic manifestations like arthritis.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which can affect the lungs primarily but also has the potential to involve the pericardium (pericarditis), kidneys (nephritis), and joints (arthropathy).

diagnoses.name: Uremia
diagnoses.description: A condition involving abnormally high levels of waste products in the blood, which can be related to renal failure leading to nephritis and can sometimes cause pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disease causing inflammation of small and medium-sized arteries, potentially affecting the kidneys (nephritis) and heart (pericarditis).

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, transmitted by ticks. It can cause a variety of symptoms, sometimes including arthritis, nephritis, and rarely, pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder similar to SLE induced by certain medications, featuring symptoms like pericarditis, arthralgia, and occasionally involving the kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the kidneys, skin, blood, and joints, causing inflammation and tissue damage in the organs involved.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause systemic manifestations including anemia and effects on organs such as the kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often accompanies other immune system disorders like rheumatoid arthritis and lupus, and can lead to nephritis along with its primary symptoms of dry eyes and mouth.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that result in the inflammation of blood vessels, which can disrupt blood flow and damage organs, potentially leading to symptoms such as rash, kidney involvement, and arthritic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that exhibits features commonly seen in lupus, scleroderma, polymyositis, and rheumatoid arthritis, including joint swelling, muscle weakness, and kidney dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. While not primarily autoimmune, it shares similar symptoms such as potential kidney involvement and arthritis.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by the body's immune system mistakenly attacking normal proteins in the blood, leading to blood clots as well as potential miscarriages and low platelet counts.

diagnoses.name: Hemolytic Anemia of Various Causes
diagnoses.description: Covers a range of autoimmune and other diseases where the immune system attacks red blood cells, leading to their premature destruction.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, leading to numerous symptoms including painful mouth sores, arthritis, and possibly affecting the brain and kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An uncommon inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. While it primarily affects skin and muscles, it can also lead to complications such as interstitial lung disease and affect other organs.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect multiple systems including the nervous system (leading to psychosis and seizures), joints (causing synovitis), and can cause pleural effusion as well as hematological abnormalities such as thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with Felty's syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: RA can cause synovitis and, in its severe form known as Felty's syndrome, can lead to thrombocytopenia and pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This is an autoimmune disorder that can cause thrombocytopenia, seizures (due to thrombosis), and pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis
diagnoses.rationale: Systemic sclerosis can lead to pleural effusion, autoimmune-mediated thrombocytopenia, and joint issues such as synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
diagnoses.rationale: This can cause a wide range of symptoms, including renal issues leading to an overlap with symptoms such as pleural effusion, potentially seizures due to CNS involvement, and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD can present with features of several autoimmune disorders, including systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, and rheumatoid arthritis, leading to synovitis, pleural effusion, thrombocytopenia, and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis can affect multiple organs and present with pleural effusion, neurological manifestations such as seizures, and less commonly thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: It's a rare condition that causes blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, including the brain (leading to seizures), and can sometimes cause thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Infectious causes (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C)
diagnoses.rationale: Both HIV and Hepatitis C can cause thrombocytopenia, and HIV can lead to neurological complications resulting in psychosis and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types of lymphoma can cause pleural effusion, thrombocytopenia due to bone marrow involvement, and systemic symptoms that may mimic autoimmune disease.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Evans Syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue, decreased libido, and muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder causing a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. Can manifest physically with chronic pain and other nonspecific symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder causing chronic inflammation of joints, which can lead to decreased libido due to overall discomfort and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that, over time, can cause some of the small bones in your spine (vertebrae) to fuse. It includes symptoms like chronic back pain.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth. It can also lead to fatigue and chronic pain.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms include fatigue, weight gain, and muscle aches.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can cause leukocytosis among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) damages the immune system and interferes with the body's ability to fight the organisms that cause disease. AIDS is the final stage of HIV infection.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that affects the way the body processes blood sugar (glucose). Can lead to neuropathy causing chronic pain and other symptoms related to the other mentioned conditions.

diagnoses: Reactive Thrombocytosis secondary to Iron Deficiency

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body including joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A cancer of plasma cells that affects bone marrow and alters blood cell production.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system, the disease-fighting network spread throughout your body.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands.

diagnoses.name: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)
diagnoses.description: A virus that damages the immune system and interferes with the body's ability to fight the organisms that cause disease.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that cannot be explained by any underlying medical condition.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells, which thickens the blood and slows its flow.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A syndrome associated with widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that occurs when the body’s immune system attacks the adrenal glands, leading to a deficiency of certain hormones.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. Features can include weight loss and abdominal pain.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation in blood vessels. Symptoms can include mouth sores, skin rashes, and abdominal pain.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that can affect the skin, mouth, and other areas, potentially causing leukoplakia-like lesions, rashes, and alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: An umbrella term for chronic inflammation of the digestive tract, primarily Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Symptoms include weight loss and abdominal pain.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition marked by a lack of enough healthy red blood cells due to too little iron, leading to fatigue, weakness, and pallor. Can be associated with celiac disease.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). Symptoms can include weight loss, leukoplakia, and general sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs, potentially causing alopecia and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
diagnoses.description: A form of skin cancer that may begin as leukoplakia. Risk factors include chronic skin injury and inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection usually spread by sexual contact that starts as a painless sore. Secondary symptoms can include rash, alopecia, and systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A nutritional condition that can lead to hair loss, diarrhea, and delayed wound healing. Can be associated with migratory abdominal pain and weight loss.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Connective tissue diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage to various body tissues including the heart and blood vessels, potentially leading to cardiomyopathy and aneurysms, as well as possibly related to angioedema and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It can lead to aneurysms, as well as potentially being related to angioedema and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An inherited disorder that affects connective tissue — most notably causing abnormalities in the heart and blood vessels, including aneurysms and possibly contributing to cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in lymphocytes (T or B cells), which are part of the immune system. It can cause lymphadenitis as one of the symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. It can cause lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that causes vasculitis, an inflammation of the blood vessels. This can lead to aneurysms and could theoretically be linked to systemic reactions including angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic disorder that results in recurring attacks of severe swelling. The swelling can occur in the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by inappropriate mast cell activation. It may be connected to various symptoms including angioedema and potentially impact heart conditions.

diagnoses.name: Fibromuscular Dysplasia
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes abnormal growth or development of cells in the walls of blood vessels, which can lead to aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease of blood vessels that can cause headaches, scalp tenderness, jaw pain, vision problems, and even aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: CVID is a disorder characterized by low levels of several immunoglobulin classes, leading to an increased susceptibility to infection. Patients may present with symptoms like decreased immunoglobulins, pneumonia, anemia, and more frequent infections.

diagnoses.name: X-Linked Agammaglobulinemia (XLA)
diagnoses.description: XLA is an inherited immunodeficiency affecting mainly males, characterized by very low or absent levels of immunoglobulins. This results in increased susceptibility to infections, including pneumonia, and may lead to lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)
diagnoses.description: SCID is a group of rare, life-threatening disorders caused by mutations in various genes involved in the development and function of T cells and B cells. Patients typically present in infancy with recurrent infections, anemia, and decreased immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD)
diagnoses.description: CGD is an inherited disorder of the immune system where certain immune cells have difficulty forming reactive oxygen species. This results in increased susceptibility to infections, including pneumonia, and can cause granuloma formation and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Selective IgA Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This is the most common primary immunodeficiency, characterized by low or absent levels of immunoglobulin A (IgA), which can lead to increased susceptibility to infections, including respiratory and gastrointestinal infections.

diagnoses.name: Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome
diagnoses.description: This is an X-linked recessive disease characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), immune deficiency, and recurrent infections. Patients can have low immunoglobulin M (IgM) levels, lymphadenitis, and pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Hyper-IgM Syndrome
diagnoses.description: This syndrome results from defects in class switch recombination, leading to elevated levels of IgM and decreased levels of other immunoglobulins, causing recurrent bacterial infections, pneumonia, and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: DiGeorge Syndrome (22q11.2 Deletion Syndrome)
diagnoses.description: A disorder that results from a defect in chromosome 22, leading to poor development of several systems. Immunodeficiency is due to thymic hypoplasia, and patients may suffer from recurrent infections, including pneumonia, and low T-cell counts.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome (ALPS)
diagnoses.description: ALPS is a disorder of abnormal lymphocyte survival, leading to lymphoproliferation and autoimmunity. Patients present with chronic nonmalignant lymphadenopathy, anemia, and increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS)
diagnoses.description: MDS are a group of disorders caused by poorly formed or dysfunctional blood cells, leading to anemia and decreased immunity. Patients may experience recurrent infections, including pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Infection
diagnoses.description: HPV infection can lead to the development of warts and, in severe cases, cervical dysplasia. Some strains are associated with an increased risk of certain cancers.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and tissue damage throughout the body including fibrosis, lymphadenitis, and potentially hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by granulomas (clusters of immune cells) in various tissues, leading to fibrosis and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause a variety of symptoms, including fibrosis in lung tissue and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which tissue that normally lines the uterus grows outside the uterus, causing severe dysmenorrhea and potentially involving immune dysregulation.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system, leading to symptoms like lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A diverse group of blood cancers that include many types, some of which involve lymphadenitis and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder affecting the immune system, causing lymphadenopathy, hypersensitivity reactions, and increased risk of autoimmune phenomena.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder of the immune system characterized by granuloma formation leading to fibrosis and increased susceptibility to infections, which may present with lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, which can lead to symptoms like hypersensitivity reactions and possibly lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system, which can cause lymphadenopathy and weight loss among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome; can cause a wide range of symptoms including lymphadenopathy and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders in which the immune system attacks the body's own tissues, potentially leading to a variety of symptoms including those listed.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders affecting the gastrointestinal tract, which can cause symptoms such as dyspepsia and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that affect the thyroid gland, which can lead to symptoms including weight loss or gain, and depression.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A serious infectious disease primarily affecting the lungs, but it can also cause lymphadenopathy and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Endometrial Cancer
diagnoses.description: Cancer that originates in the lining of the uterus (endometrium); could be considered particularly in the context of endometriosis and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing symptoms such as weight loss and dyspepsia.

diagnoses: Nausea and Vomiting (associated with Gastroparesis or UTI)
Monocytosis (could be secondary to infection or inflammation)
Diabetes Mellitus (can be associated with Gastroparesis and higher risk of UTI)
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) (symptoms can overlap with Gastroparesis, such as nausea)
Upper Respiratory Tract Infection (can be associated with Otitis Media)
Acute Pyelonephritis (a type of UTI that has ascended to the kidney, potentially relevant with monocytosis indicating an immune response)
Systemic Infection or Inflammatory Disease (could potentially explain a combination of these symptoms including monocytosis)
Eczema (including Otitis Externa as a complication)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.reason: While not fitting all symptoms directly, psoriasis can cause nail changes similar to onychodystrophy and has been associated with systemic symptoms that could align with some mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.reason: This disease often presents with migratory erythema (erythema migrans) and could indirectly lead to or exacerbate other mentioned symptoms through systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reason: A multisystem inflammatory disorder that can lead to various symptoms including hypersensitivity reactions and skin changes, although it is less commonly associated with onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation affecting the skin, heart (palpitations), and potentially leading to hypersensitivity reactions. However, direct association with onychodystrophy or hemorrhoids is less common.

diagnoses.name: Erythema Multiforme

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Also known as 'mono', this infection can cause swollen lymph nodes, fever, sore throat, and fatigue, along with skin rashes that might mimic folliculitis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that can cause a wide range of symptoms in various stages, including skin rashes that may resemble folliculitis, swollen lymph nodes, and other systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Skin Infections and Infestations
diagnoses.description: Various pathogens (bacterial, viral, fungal) and infestations (such as scabies) can directly cause folliculitis and Lymphadenopathy. Secondary bacterial infection can deteriorate periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Though less directly related, hypothyroidism can lead to a myriad of symptoms including skin changes that might increase susceptibility to infections like folliculitis, and could potentially contribute to hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: This autoimmune disorder can cause systemic effects including Lymphadenopathy. It may also indirectly contribute to periodontal disease due to the overall impact on health including that of the skin.

diagnoses.name: Heart Disease
diagnoses.description: While not directly causing folliculitis or Lymphadenopathy, heart disease can be a comorbid condition with hypertension, and the overall health impact could exacerbate conditions like periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Primary Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A rare type of bone marrow cancer that disrupts the body's normal production of blood cells, causing extensive scarring in bone marrow. This can lead to anemia, weakness, fatigue, and often an enlarged spleen. Symptoms such as thrombocytopenia and thromboembolic disease can be manifestations of this condition.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body produces too many platelets, leading to blood clotting or bleeding complications. It can present with thrombocytopenia if there is increased platelet consumption or destruction, or with thromboembolic disease due to abnormal platelet function.

diagnoses.name: Hughes Syndrome (Antiphospholipid Syndrome)
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder that increases the risk of blood clots. This syndrome may present with thromboembolic disease and can be associated with various reproductive issues in women, including delayed puberty in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects a woman's hormone levels, leading to the development of cysts on the ovaries, often associated with delayed puberty. It can also potentially correlate with thrombosis risk in severe cases due to hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. Over time, this reaction damages your small intestine's lining and prevents absorption of some nutrients. The intestinal damage often causes constipation, among other symptoms. Delayed puberty can also occur due to malnutrition.

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chromosomal disorder that affects only females, characterized by the partial or complete loss of one of the X chromosomes. Symptoms may include delayed puberty and congenital thrombophilia, which increases the risk of thromboembolic disease.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder caused by deficient or defective von Willebrand factor, a clotting protein. While primarily known to cause bleeding, it can occasionally cause thrombocytopenia and has been associated with menstrual irregularities that could mimic endometriosis symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, heart, lungs, blood vessels, and brain. It can cause a wide variety of symptoms, including thrombocytopenia and thromboembolic disease. Congestion and other symptoms could be manifestations of organ involvement.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland is underactive and does not produce enough thyroid hormones, leading to a wide range of symptoms, including constipation, delayed puberty, and menstrual irregularities which could be confused with endometriosis.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that causes blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. The disease can lead to numerous signs and symptoms that may mimic other conditions, including thrombosis and gastrointestinal symptoms like constipation.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue, pain, and dizziness that worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. The exact cause is unknown, but various triggering events have been proposed.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A common disorder affecting the large intestine, causing symptoms like cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea or constipation, or both. IBS is a chronic condition that needs to be managed long term.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Hypothyroidism's symptoms include fatigue, increased sensitivity to cold, constipation, dry skin, weight gain, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Researchers believe fibromyalgia amplifies painful sensations by affecting the way your brain processes pain signals.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS may have infrequent or prolonged menstrual periods or excess male hormone (androgen) levels. The ovaries may develop numerous small collections of fluid (follicles) and fail to regularly release eggs.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body. The weakness tends to increase with activity and improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. Over time, this reaction damages your small intestine's lining and prevents absorption of some nutrients (malabsorption).

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A painful disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that normally lines the inside of your uterus — the endometrium — grows outside your uterus. It commonly involves your ovaries, fallopian tubes, and the tissue lining your pelvis.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition in which mast cells inappropriately release chemical mediators, resulting in a range of chronic symptoms, possibly including dermatographism and anaphylaxis.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It can explain hypermobility, potentially contribute to weight loss, and might be associated indirectly with increased susceptibility to infections due to skin and mucosal vulnerabilities.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome can lead to a severe and often fatal condition, leading to significant weight loss and increased susceptibility to infections due to the immune system's weakening.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: Systemic lupus erythematosus is a chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of the body, often leading to weight loss, increased susceptibility to infections, and can have cardiovascular effects like postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS).

diagnoses.name: Cystic Fibrosis
diagnoses.description: A hereditary disorder affecting the exocrine glands, causing the production of abnormally thick mucus, leading to the blockage of the pancreatic ducts, intestines, and bronchi and often resulting in respiratory infections and fibrosis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. In some patients, it can lead to weight loss, fibrosis, and an increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue, providing strength, flexibility, and elasticity to the structure of the body. It can be associated with hypermobility and potential cardiovascular issues.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders wherein parts of the body's immune system are missing or functioning improperly, causing increased susceptibility to infections, among other issues.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. While it doesn’t explain all symptoms, it can lead to weight loss and has been associated with an increased risk of infections due to both the disease and its treatments.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that affect how your body uses blood sugar (glucose). Although it doesn't cover all symptoms, diabetes can lead to weight loss (especially in type 1), and susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: An antibody deficiency that leads to an increased susceptibility to infections, which can cause chronic lung disease and can result in weight loss and potentially affect the gastrointestinal tract, leading to malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin Lymphoma

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia

diagnoses.name: Syphilis

diagnoses.name: Lupus

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis

diagnoses.name: Vitamin C Deficiency (Scurvy)
diagnoses.description: While more rare in modern diets, vitamin C deficiency can lead to poor healing, and in advanced cases, can contribute to immune system weakening, potentially aggravating conditions like lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. Eye irritation and obsessive-compulsive behavior can be associated symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder that can manifest physically, causing chronic tiredness, obsessive-compulsive behavior, and occasional physical symptoms like anemia.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism can cause anemia, alopecia, and eye irritation due to hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that produce saliva and tears, leading to dry eyes, amongst other symptoms like fatigue and potential anemia.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: Mental health conditions that can manifest in various physical ways, including obsessive-compulsive behavior, laryngitis from stress-induced vocal strain, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease known for its wide range of symptoms, including joint pain, rash, and eye irritation, as well as more severe complications like anemia.

diagnoses.name: Psychiatric Disorders
diagnoses.description: Various mental health disorders can lead to physical manifestations or exacerbated symptoms, including obsessive-compulsive behavior, potential anemia due to nutritional deficiencies, and alopecia from stress.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys don't work as well as they should. It can affect anyone, but it's more common in people who are black or of south Asian origin.

diagnoses.name: Acute Otitis Media
diagnoses.description: An infection of the middle ear that is especially common in children. It can cause pain, fever, and difficulty hearing.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition that affects the way the body processes blood sugar (glucose). Diabetes can lead to CKD and contribute to symptoms like dysgeusia (altered taste).

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing symptoms such as malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A brain disorder marked by an ongoing pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells, often causing symptoms like malabsorption and altered taste.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: Also known as high blood pressure, it can result from or lead to chronic kidney disease, impacting overall health.

diagnoses.name: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.description: An overactivity of one or more of the parathyroid glands, which can lead to calcium imbalances, potentially affecting kidney function and bone health.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic digestive disease where stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe lining, potentially leading to or complicating dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A nutritional deficiency that can cause symptoms such as altered taste (dysgeusia) and malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur rapidly. Symptoms can include skin reactions such as itching (pruritis), a rapid drop in blood pressure leading to fainting (syncope), and abdominal cramps. Conjunctival injection might also be observed due to the systemic allergic response.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, leading to demyelination and a wide range of symptoms. These can include neurological symptoms like incontinence and syncope, and less commonly, pruritis.

diagnoses.name: Acute Intermittent Porphyria
diagnoses.description: A rare metabolic disorder that can cause a wide range of symptoms including abdominal cramps, incontinence, and nervous system issues. Syncope may occur during acute attacks.

diagnoses.name: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
diagnoses.description: An infection of the female reproductive organs. It can cause lower abdominal pain (cramps), urinary incontinence, and in severe cases, symptoms like syncope from severe pain or systemic infection.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS)
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain bacterial infections. Symptoms can include high fever, rash, conjunctival injection, severe abdominal cramps, and a sudden drop in blood pressure leading to syncope.

diagnoses.name: Severe Dehydration
diagnoses.description: Loss of water and salts essential for normal body function can lead to decreased blood volume, possibly causing syncope (fainting) and abdominal cramps. Pruritis might not be directly related but can occur due to skin dryness associated with dehydration.

diagnoses.name: Neurogenic Bladder Dysfunction
diagnoses.description: A dysfunction in the bladder's normal nerve function that can lead to urinary incontinence. Associated neurological conditions might also present with syncope and/or abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that occurs when your body produces insufficient amounts of certain hormones produced by your adrenal glands. It can cause abdominal cramps, incontinence, and skin changes like pruritis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the skin (causing pruritis), kidneys (leading to incontinence), and nervous system (potential for syncope).

diagnoses.name: Carcinoid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A syndrome occurring in patients with carcinoid tumors, characterized by flushing, abdominal cramps, and, in severe cases, heart valve problems which might lead to syncope. Incontinence and pruritis are less common but possible symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around your nerve fibers, leading to delayed response or permanent nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells start to die within minutes.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that might occur with symptoms such as visual disturbances (scintillation), and numbness or tingling (paresthesia).

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke', it's a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke. It can cause temporary difficulty with speech, movement, and vision.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that causes muscles weakness and rapid fatigue. It can cause problems with vision, swallowing (dysphagia), speech, and keeping the head upright.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to muscle weakness and numbness that can escalate to paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the vestibular nerve that can cause vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. It can affect brain function depending on the area and size, leading to various neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A neurological disease that causes muscle weakness and impacts physical function. It can lead to difficulties with speech, swallowing, and other motor functions.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: Damage to your peripheral nerves, often causing weakness, numbness, and pain, typically in the hands and feet. It can also affect other areas and body functions including digestion, urination, and circulation.
An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing weakness, coordination, balance difficulties, and other problems.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, paralysis or weakness in the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body, trouble speaking or understanding speech, and loss of balance or coordination.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms include numbness or weakness in one or more limbs, partial or complete loss of vision, prolonged double vision, tingling or pain in parts of your body, and problems with balance and coordination.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a type of headache that can cause severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, usually on one side of the head. Migraine with aura is a classic type of migraine that involves special warning symptoms (the aura) 10 to 30 minutes before the migraine headache begins. Symptoms of the aura phase may include visual phenomena, such as seeing various shapes, bright spots or flashes of light, speech and language problems, pins and needles sensations in an arm or leg, and weakness or numbness in the face or one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: A transient ischemic attack (TIA), often called a 'mini-stroke,' is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. Often a warning sign of a future stroke, symptoms can include numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body, confusion or trouble speaking or understanding speech, trouble seeing in one or both eyes, and dizziness or loss of balance or coordination.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: Peripheral neuropathy, a result of damage to the nerves located outside of the brain and spinal cord (peripheral nerves), often causes weakness, numbness, and pain, usually in your hands and feet. It can also affect other areas and body functions including digestion, urination, and circulation. Symptoms include pain, stabbing, burning or tingling sensations, muscle weakness, and sensitivity to touch.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain or close to your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Symptoms can vary greatly depending on the brain tumor's size, location and rate of growth. Common symptoms include new onset or change in pattern of headaches, unexplained nausea or vomiting, vision problems, loss of sensation or movement in an arm or a leg, difficulty with balance, speech difficulties, confusion in everyday matters, and personality or behavior changes.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Vestibular neuritis is an inflammation of the vestibular nerve, a nerve in the ear that helps control balance. This condition can cause sudden, severe vertigo and may be associated with hearing loss. Symptoms include a sudden onset of vertigo, dizziness, imbalance, difficulty focusing the eyes, and nausea and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body. In its most severe form Guillain-Barré syndrome is a medical emergency. It can interfere with breathing and, at times, with blood pressure or heart rate.

diagnoses.name: Ménière's Disease
diagnoses.description: Ménière's Disease is a disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In most cases, Ménière's disease affects only one ear. Symptoms can include recurring episodes of vertigo, hearing loss, ringing in the ear (tinnitus), and a feeling of fullness or pressure in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Bell's Palsy
diagnoses.description: Bell's palsy is a condition that causes a temporary weakness or paralysis of the muscles in the face. It can occur when the nerve that controls your facial muscles becomes inflamed, swollen, or compressed. The condition causes one side of your face to droop or become stiff. You might have difficulty smiling or closing your eye on the affected side. In some cases, Bell's palsy can also affect your sense of taste and how you make tears and saliva.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing weakness, coordination, balance difficulties, and other problems.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines that involve visual disturbances (such as scintillations) and other sensory changes.

diagnoses.name: Brainstem Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurring in the brainstem can affect balance, swallowing, speaking, and other vital body functions.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, leading to loss of muscle control.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which can lead to dysarthria and dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder where the body's immune system attacks the nerves, leading to weakness, numbness, and possibly ataxia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Tumors in the brain can press on areas controlling speech, swallowing, and balance, potentially leading to these symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Cerebellar Ataxia
diagnoses.description: A condition that involves the cerebellum, part of the brain that controls movement coordination and balance.

diagnoses.name: Wilson Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare inherited disorder that causes copper to accumulate in the liver, brain, and other vital organs, leading to neurological symptoms.
A stroke can lead to various neurological symptoms depending on the area of the brain affected, including speech and swallowing difficulties, and balance issues.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden weakness, difficulty speaking or understanding speech, and visual problems.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often referred to as a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. Symptoms are similar to a stroke and can include paralysis, aphasia, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, ALS is a neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord, leading to muscle weakness, dysphagia, and eventually, paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: MS is a disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including muscle weakness, difficulty with coordination and balance, speech problems, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: This is a chronic autoimmune disorder in which antibodies destroy the communication between nerves and muscle, resulting in weakness of the skeletal muscles. Symptoms can include dysphagia, weakness, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant). Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, problems with vision, weakness, and speech or language difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barré syndrome is a rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing the whole body.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines with aura involve severe headache pain often accompanied by visual disturbances (scintillation), sensory problems, or other types of disruptions that appear before the headache. Common symptoms include seeing bright spots or flashes of light.

diagnoses.name: Primary Progressive Aphasia
diagnoses.description: This is a rare neurological syndrome in which language capabilities become slowly and progressively impaired. It is classified under the broader condition frontotemporal dementia. Symptoms primarily include difficulty speaking or understanding speech.

diagnoses.name: Stroke-like Migraine Attacks after Radiation Therapy (SMART) Syndrome
diagnoses.description: SMART syndrome is a delayed complication of radiation therapy to the brain, characterized by several symptoms that mimic those of a stroke, including migraines, seizures, aphasia, and weakness.

A type of headache characterized by neurological phenomena (aura) that precedes the headache. Symptoms can include visual disturbances (scintillations, scotoma), sensory changes (paresthesia), and speech or language abnormalities (aphasia).

Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a TIA is a brief interruption of blood flow to part of the brain, spinal cord, or retina, which may cause symptoms like vertigo, aphasia, and paresthesia without lasting damage.
A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include aphasia, parasthesia, and in some cases, vision problems like scotomas.
A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include vertigo, paresthesia, and in later stages, issues with speech (aphasia).

A central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Visual and sensory disturbances can occur.
An abnormal mass of cells growing in the brain that can lead to a variety of neurological symptoms, depending on the location, including aphasia, paresthesia, and visual disturbances.
A condition resulting from the reduction of blood flow to the back part of the brain. Symptoms can include vertigo, visual disturbances like scotoma, and speech difficulties.

A condition caused by a very low level of blood sugar (glucose), your body's main energy source. It can cause symptoms like visual disturbances, paresthesia, and in severe cases, neurological impairments like aphasia.
An inner ear infection that can cause vertigo and hearing loss. While it is less likely to cause the full range of symptoms listed, in severe cases it can be accompanied by neurological symptoms.
A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In rare cases, it may be associated with tinnitus, fullness in the ears, and muffled hearing.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms including severe headaches, phonophobia (sensitivity to sound), and visual disturbances. Weakness, dysarthria (difficulty in speech), and numbness can also be associated during a complex or atypical migraine aura.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: A medical emergency where the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, causing brain cells to die. Symptoms can include sudden onset of weakness, headache, dysarthria, numbness, and other neurological deficits.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: A disease of the central nervous system that can lead to fatigue, weakness, dysarthria, numbness, and headache. Phonophobia is not a typical symptom but can occur in some individuals.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can vary widely but may include headaches, weakness, numbness, dysarthria, and various neurologic symptoms depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.details: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA produces similar symptoms to a stroke (weakness, headache, phonophobia, dysarthria, numbness) but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.details: An inner ear disorder that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In some cases, it can cause headaches, a sensitivity to sound (phonophobia), and a feeling of aural fullness, though weakness, dysarthria, and numbness are less common.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are the first symptoms, followed by numbness, and possibly dysarthria if cranial nerves are involved.

diagnoses.name: Viral Meningitis
diagnoses.details: An infection of the meninges, the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include headache, fever, stiff neck, or sensitivity to light (photophobia). Phonophobia, weakness, dysarthria, and numbness can also be present.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.details: Bleeding into the space between the brain and the surrounding membrane, often caused by the rupture of a brain aneurysm. Symptoms include sudden severe headache, nausea, vomiting, reduced alertness, and potentially numbness, weakness, and dysarthria based on the bleed's location.

diagnoses.name: Hemiplegic Migraine
diagnoses.details: A rare type of migraine where auras are accompanied by temporary paralysis or weakness on one side of the body (hemiplegia), sensory disturbances including numbness, dysarthria, and phonophobia along with a severe headache.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, presenting with a wide range of symptoms including rash, arthritis, and kidney problems.

diagnoses.name: Viral infection
diagnoses.details: Several viruses can cause these symptoms, including Coxsackievirus, Echovirus, and HIV. Viral infections can lead to conditions such as viral pericarditis and a secondary rash.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory disease that can develop after a Group A Streptococcus infection. It can affect the heart, joints, skin, and brain, leading to symptoms such as a rash, carditis, and cranial neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.details: A rare autoimmune disorder that has features of three other connective tissue diseases: lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. It can present with a wide array of symptoms including those listed.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. In some cases, it can affect the heart (pericarditis), skin (rash), and nervous system (cranial neuropathy).

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.details: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. The disease can lead to numerous signs and symptoms that may mimic those of many other diseases, including rashes and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It can occasionally affect the heart and present with symptoms such as pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.details: Often caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can present with a maculopapular rash, especially after certain antibiotics, and has been associated with cranial neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.details: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, transmitted by ticks. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including rash, neurological, and cardiac symptoms, depending on the stage of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Endocarditis
diagnoses.details: An infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and heart valves (endocardium). It's rare but can cause a wide range of symptoms, including heart and kidney problems.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease can present with neurological symptoms (delirium, seizures), hematological abnormalities (thrombocytopenia), renal involvement (proteinuria), and dermatological manifestations (malar rash).

diagnoses.name: Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)
diagnoses.rationale: TTP can present with a pentad of symptoms including thrombocytopenia and neurological symptoms such as seizures or delirium. Proteinuria may occur due to kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)
diagnoses.rationale: APS is characterized by thrombotic events and/or pregnancy-related complications in the presence of persistently elevated levels of antiphospholipid antibodies. It can present with neurological manifestations (seizures, delirium), thrombocytopenia, and renal issues (proteinuria).

diagnoses.name: Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)
diagnoses.rationale: DIC is a serious condition affecting the blood's clotting mechanism, leading to both thrombosis and hemorrhage. It can present with thrombocytopenia, seizures (due to hemorrhagic events), and proteinuria due to kidney damage.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: A group of disorders that destroy blood vessels by inflammation. It can present with a variety of symptoms including skin rashes (such as a malar rash), neurological symptoms (seizures, delirium), and kidney involvement (proteinuria).

diagnoses.name: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS)
diagnoses.rationale: HUS typically presents with three main features: acute renal failure (proteinuria), thrombocytopenia, and hemolytic anemia. Neurological symptoms may also appear.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: While technically a manifestation of SLE, lupus nephritis specifically refers to the kidney involvement in SLE, presenting with significant proteinuria and possibly thrombocytopenia and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Epileptic Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Primary seizure disorders usually don’t cause thrombocytopenia or proteinuria directly but can coexist in complex cases with underlying systemic diseases that also present with delirium and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Diseases (e.g., Meningitis)
diagnoses.rationale: Some infections, like meningitis, can present with seizures, delirium, a rash, and in more severe cases, organ dysfunction leading to symptoms like proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Toxic or Drug-induced Conditions
diagnoses.rationale: Various toxins or drugs can induce a state of delirium, seizures, thrombocytopenia (through bone marrow suppression or immune mechanisms), and proteinuria due to kidney injury.
